description: A hidden question block that blocks a jump or creates a soft-lock.
A level which has at least three Bowser, Bowser Jr., Meowser, Boom Boom, or Pom Pom enemies in it.
A jump in the level where the player is unable to see where or if a safe landing area exists until after Mario jumps.
A level which requires the player to kill Yoshi in order to advance.
A level with the "Reach the goal without landing after touching the ground" clear condition, where the majority of the level involves staying off of the ground after an initial jump.

A level with the "Reach the goal without landing after touching the ground" clear condition, where the majority of the level involves not jumping at all and using moving platforms to change Mario's position.
A block (question, note, brick, etc.) that, when hit, generates a boo ring.
A path (door, pipe, or otherwise) not intended to be found by the player, which trivializes the level.
A level requiring the player to open a path by exploding bob-ombs, kicking shells, or manipulating Bowser to destroy blocks.
A level requiring the player to advance by destroying blocks that create a scroll stop three or more times.
A coin path, which, if followed by the player, results in death or other reversal of level progress.
A door which, when taken, immediately leads to Mario's death. The player must actually die from such a door to count.
A point in the level where the player must choose between multiple identical options (doors, pipes, etc.) without being able to tell which choice is correct.
A level where the sub-area is vertical, and the player is racing the lava/poison/other danger that is rising from the bottom of the screen.
A genuine puzzle level. Mazes do not count as puzzles.
A level that requires using a red Yoshi to beat the level.
A level that requires the player to collect all of the coins on the level to open the exit, or that requires the player to collect a minimum number of coins to open the exit.

A level where getting an item that is normally considered "good" (such as a power-up, star, or P-switch) causes Mario to die or the level to be otherwise unbeatable. Level must contain multiple copies of this item.
A level where, if the wrong path is taken, the player is forced to hit a checkpoint for a loss of progress.
A level where the exit is mostly covered with blocks or enemies, leaving only a small section exposed.
The player gets in a position where they are unable to continue progress in the level, due to getting Mario stuck, losing a required powerup, etc. This counts even if suicide is an option.
A level which starts with fewer than 100 seconds on the timer.
A level heavily featuring the wall jump mechanic.
A level heavily featuring the On/Off switch for blocks, conveyors, tracks, etc.
Pipes in a level where the back end is not attached to anything.
A level that kills you if you jump too many times.
A hidden block containing an item required to complete the level. Does not count if the block is overly hinted at (for example multiple arrows pointing at it).
A level requiring Mario to spin jump off at least three enemies to complete.
The player yells at the level designer, usually because of unfair item/enemy placement (see the Intermediate tutorial "Treating the Player Fairly").
An arrow, which, if followed by the player, results in death or other reversal of level progress.
Mario will be killed by a hazard other than a thwomp at the start of the level unless he moves out of the way as soon as the level starts.
The level gives the player 3 or more 1-ups in a single life.
The title of the level is bad, for any number of reasons (begging for likes, etc).
The player is able to skip large portions of the level by subverting an obstacle.
A level with a lot of Cat Bell powerups and/or a lot of enemies with Cat Bells applied to them.
The player chooses to skip a level for any reason.
The upside-down mechanic is used in the level.
Player achieved the world recoord time for a level.
Player was the first person to clear the level.
Every question mark block in the level contains an enemy.
A Cheep-Cheep kills the player.
A speedrun level in the New Super Mario Brothers theme.
A large number of sound effects are placed in the level, to the annoyance of everyone.
A Lakitu cloud or a cape is used to skip large portions of the level.
The level forces you to have Yoshi at the end of the level, with or without a clear condition for Yoshi.
The level was not total garbage (does not imply the player Liked the level).
The Silence SFX is used in the level to remove the music.
The level utilizes a glitch in order for the player to complete it.
The level is copied from an official Mario level.
The level is a modified version of an official Mario level.
The level uses autoscrolling for a majority of the level.
Multiple Bowsers or other bosses placed on top of each other.
An inordinate number of enemies fill part of the level.
A maze of spikes must be navigated to get to the end of the level.
There are red coins in the level that unlock an optional path.
The player is able to skip key doors and end the level with at least one key in their possession.
The level was made to trick the player in one or more ways.
Running across strings of P-Switches is required to get to the end of the level.
A giant Bowser/Meowser that must be killed with Fire Flower fireballs is present in the level.
A level with many precise platforming sections.
A Kamek enemy is placed in a way that it despawns the goal and must be killed.
The player's path off/from the exit causes them to "die" after achieving victory.
The level contains one or more sections of surviving a room until a red coin becomes available to obtain.
The player must make a shell jump, spring jump, or POW jump to advance in the level.
The player must make a P-Switch jump to advance in the level.
The player must make a mid-air (usually frame-perfect) jump to advance in the level.
The same level appears more than once in the same run.
A level gets a deserved Like from the player.
A level gets a deserved Boo from the player.
Another player picked up the player and threw them into death (pit, enemy, etc).
The player picked up another player and threw them into death (pit, enemy, etc).
A communications error occurs and ends the level early.
Two or more players finish the level within a few frames of each other.
A multiplayer level with a large space for the players to fight over the clear condition.
A multiplayer level with On/Off switches or P-Switches that kill other players when they are hit.
A level has features that only work in single player and cause the level to be unfinishable in multiplayer if any player fails a challenge (e.g. relies on respawning enemies by moving offscreen).
A level has features that only work for a single player at a time, causing others to have to wait (rising lava in a sub area, snake blocks to cross gaps, non-pipe item respawns).
A level designed such that each player has their own path to follow.
Some automatic device/gizmo causes the player to have to wait at least two seconds to advance in the level.
